video.title: DOOM: The Dark Ages | Fully Ramblomatic

captions.text:
I believe I said when I first saw the Doom: 
The Dark Ages trailer that I was getting

distinctly &quot;midlife crisis&quot; vibes from 
it. I mean, not only does Mr. D. Slayer,

esquire have a shiny new shield that literally has 
a pull chain on it like it&#39;s a fucking lawnmower,

but he also seems to be wearing a new toupee that 
keeps slipping and hanging around the back of his

neck. But then I remembered that Doom 3 had been 
Doom&#39;s real midlife crisis when it showed up in a

shiny new engine covered in chrome and expensive 
lights and pretended like it was still one of the

cool kids. Then there was Doom 2016, which for 
me represented a sort of partial regression to

childhood state not uncommon in age-related 
dementia, and I suppose following that logic,

Doom: The Dark Ages represents the natural next 
step. Being dead. Being dead and having your

horrible corpse puppeted around on a stick so 
that your current owner can continue collecting

your pension cheques. Okay, I&#39;m slightly 
overstating things for outrage dollars,

but I am genuinely disappointed that Dark 
Ages continues a slide that began in Doom

Eternal wherein the game&#39;s story element 
began losing its sense of self-awareness.

The Doom Slayer no longer fist bumps his action 
figures or gleefully smashes a thing moments

after being very politely asked not to smash 
the thing or walks through a roomful of humans

while they all visibly brick themselves like 
he&#39;s an unsecured gorilla who&#39;s outwardly calm

but could at any moment mistake any of their 
todgers for an unclaimed banana. No, now he

just goes around exchanging respectful nods with 
supermarket-own-brand Warhammer 40k characters

and rescuing fucking princesses. We literally 
rescue a princess at one point in Dark Ages,

one who is a human vessel for a mysterious ancient 
power, just in case you were afraid the green

outfit was the only thing justifying the Legend 
of Zelda comparison. They don&#39;t even call him the

Doom Slayer anymore. Now, he&#39;s just The Slayer. 
Which is infinitely less fun to say. Anyway,

the story is Dermot Sebastian Layer is being 
held prisoner by the Maykrs and being loaned

out to the Sentinels of Argent The Noo to 
aid in their war against the forces of Grand

Prince Arsehole, who is teaming up with a new 
other-dimensional faction with Lovecraft-y vibes,

but the alliance is an uneasy one and threatens 
to create a schism between—blah de blah de blah.

I have a feeling there&#39;s someone on the dev 
team who&#39;s using this franchise to bring to

life their epic fantasy novel series that keeps 
getting rejected by publishers, and none of it

is adding much value because it&#39;s so painfully 
generic, offers me no characters to root for,

and frankly, I enjoyed Doom a lot more when 
the plot was just &quot;Dude really hates demons,

and some demons exist.&quot; Gosh, things 
got a bit heavy for a while there;

let&#39;s blow off some steam by killing literally 
hundreds of fucking dudes. Gameplay-wise,

the evolution of the neo-Doom formula has 
largely been a matter of scale. We&#39;ve left

far behind the enclosed Mars bases and steel 
corridors of Doom 2016, mysteriously roomy as

those were. The average level in The Dark Ages 
is like a square mile of Hell countryside where

we wipe out entire battalions of zombie men 
with a single fling of our mighty lawnmower

shield. Compensating for the larger distances 
with a new superfast charge move where we ride

our shield like it&#39;s the motorbike we didn&#39;t 
tell our wife we were going to buy. It&#39;s like,

after everyone hated fighting that one shield 
guy in the last game, the developer apparently

thought that what we were complaining about 
was how they were hogging all the shield fun.

So now, shields galore. You&#39;ve got a 
shield. A bunch more of the monsters

have shields. They hired Brooke Shields 
as a voice actor—they didn&#39;t, actually;

I was just going with a riff—and consequently, 
a lot of the core gameplay is based around the

shield. And initially, I thought holding up your 
little saucepan lid to nope out of attacks might

mess with the established Doom 2016 watchwords of 
&quot;stay mobile and be aggressive,&quot; but in practice,

the ridiculous speed and range of the shield bash 
helps it slot into the over-the-top super violence

quite nicely. Similarly, I really thought 
I&#39;d hate the new parry mechanic more. &quot;Oh,

when the hell did Doom become about being reactive 
and waiting for THEM to attack?&quot; I thought. &quot;Seems

a bit out of character for a dude who&#39;s spent the 
previous two games using their own spiny todgers

to very proactively scout demons as clients 
for his tonsillectomy clinic,&quot; but in practice,

you can only parry attacks of a certain color, 
Cuphead style, and it&#39;s just another thing you

have to split-second react to. A little too 
generous with the timing and range, perhaps,

but the way Neo-Doom always obsessively 
unlocks new weapons and superpowers all the

way to the end until you&#39;ve got 12 guns, three 
tactical nuclear strikes, and rabid wolverines

strapped to both kneecaps, getting too easy 
is consistent with the established pattern.

I&#39;d say the Glory Kills have been 
downgraded a bit. Half the time,

I didn&#39;t even get a special animation; he&#39;d just 
do a little huffy shove or kick that makes dude&#39;s

arms and legs all fly off. But my real bugbear 
is the way the critical path keeps forcing us

into recurring vehicle sections. Especially the 
ones where you pilot a giant mech, which falls

into the usual problem with such things—it 
plays exactly the same as regular gameplay,

except you move around like the floor&#39;s covered 
in overly affectionate vaginas. And only fight

one kind of enemy. With one attack that&#39;s about 
as hard to dodge as an awkward question in the

middle of a flash flood. The bits where you ride 
on a flying dragon are better &#39;cause you have a

better freedom of movement to help you appreciate 
the scale and spectacle of the environments,

but again, when it comes to fighting things, 
all the variety and strategy of the standard

combat is replaced with &quot;point at the dude, mash 
your one attack, get out of the way of their one

attack.&quot; And it&#39;s like the spectacular wrestling 
match had to stop so the participants could sit

down in the middle of the ring and decide the 
result with a round of Hungry Hungry Hippos.

So, to summarize, what recommends Dark Age of 
Doomelot is more high-octane core combat and some

nice spectacle. I mean, look up at the sky during 
one of the levels in Lovecraft World, and you&#39;ll

see a fucking mind-blowingly huge horrifying 
space octopus drifting aimlessly about like

it&#39;s waiting for Mrs. Horrifying Space Octopus to 
come out of the bra shop. But ultimately, I came

away feeling like I&#39;d had a hollow experience. The 
central joke and novelty of being this taciturn,

faceless super badass who gives less shit than 
a taped up bumhole in the Sahara desert has

worn thin, and the series has lost sight of the 
core philosophy that made Doom 2016 work, i.e.,

simplicity. All this cosmic multifaction conflict 
rubbish we&#39;re obliged to give some of our precious

little available shit about and How to Train 
Your Cybernetic Nightmare Dragon sequences

feel like stuff put in more to create trailer 
moments than to enrich the gameplay experience.

The Doom guy worked best when he was just a guy 
with no motivation in life except to expand his

spiny todger collection. &#39;Cause turns out, that 
syncs up pretty well with MY motivation as a

player. Although he can keep the spiny todgers; I 
already repaired the wonky leg on my coffee table.
